qas.question: How many components does the Belgian political landscape include?
What are the two components in the Belgian political landscape?

answers.text: the Dutch-speaking population represented by Dutch-language political parties, and the majority populations of Wallonia and Brussels

qas.question: What component is the Brussel Region?
What happens with the Brussels special position?

answers.text: consequently has a number of political issues

qas.question: How many components does the Belgian political landscape exclude?
How many components doesn't the Belgian political landscape include?

plausible_answers.text: the Dutch-speaking population represented by Dutch-language political parties, and the majority populations of Wallonia and Brussels

qas.question: What are the three components in the Belgian political landscape?
What component isn't the Brussel Region?

plausible_answers.text: has a number of political issues

qas.question: What happens without the Brussels special position?

context: On one hand, this means that the Belgian political landscape, generally speaking, consists of only <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>two components<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>: <a1_0><b6_0>the Dutch-speaking population represented by Dutch-language political parties, and the majority populations of Wallonia and Brussels<b6_0/><a1_0/>, represented by their French-speaking parties. The Brussels region emerges as a <a2_0><b7_0>third component<b7_0/><a2_0/>. This specific dual form of federalism, with the special position of Brussels, <a3_0>consequently <b8_0>has a number of political issues<b8_0/><a3_0/>—even minor ones—that are being fought out over the Dutch/French-language political division. With such issues, a final decision is possible only in the form of a compromise. This tendency gives this dual federalism model a number of traits that generally are ascribed to confederalism, and makes the future of Belgian federalism contentious.
